titleStmt.title: AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 1 Benchmarking Automation-Aided Performance in a Forensic Face Matching Task

affiliation.orgName: Faculty of Health and Medical Sciences
Faculty of Health and Medical Sciences

analytic.title: AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 1 Benchmarking Automation-Aided Performance in a Forensic Face Matching Task

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Carragher and Hancock (2023) investigated how individuals performed in a one-to-one face matching task when assisted by an Automated Facial Recognition System (AFRS). Across five pre-registered experiments they found evidence of suboptimal aided performance, with AFRSassisted individuals consistently failing to reach the level of performance the AFRS achieved alone. The current study reanalyses these data (Carragher & Hancock, 2023), to benchmark automation-aided performance against a series of statistical models of collaborative decision making, spanning a range of efficiency levels. Analyses using a Bayesian hierarchical signal detection model revealed that collaborative performance was highly inefficient, falling closest to the most suboptimal models of automation dependence tested. This pattern of results generalises previous reports of suboptimal human-automation interaction across a range of visual search, target detection, sensory discrimination, and numeric estimation decision-making tasks. The current study is the first to provide benchmarks of automation-aided performance in the one-toone face matching task.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Security and law enforcement operations often require agents to verify an individual's identity by checking the person's appearance against a photo identification document (photo ID). This type of one-to-one face matching task is conducted at border control, for instance, where agents compare the current appearance of a traveller to the image in the passport they present for inspection. Despite the common suggestion that humans are "face experts" (Diamond & Carey, 1986), accuracy in perceptual matching tasks is generally only high for familiar faces (Megreya & Burton, 2006;Noyes & Jenkins, 2019;Young & Burton, 2018).

Accuracy verifying the identity of unfamiliar faces is relatively poor, often falling between 60-80%, depending on the standardised face-matching task (e.g., Burton et al., 2010;Fysh & Bindemann, 2018b;. Performance is worse if the images are pixelated (Bindemann et al., 2013), obstructed (Carragher & Hancock, 2020), aged (Megreya et al., 2013), captured from different cameras (Burton et al., 2010), or varied in any of many other ways (for review see Fysh & Bindemann, 2017). Although there is little evidence that ability improves with practice or training (Towler et al., 2019;c.f. Towler et al., 2021), some individuals can achieve exceptional face matching accuracy, including "super-recognisers" (Bobak et al., 2016) and specialist facial examiners (Phillips et al., 2018;).
Yet, the average performance of professionals in roles requiring face matching is often similar to that of untrained student participants (White et al., 2014).

Given these limitations on human performance, Automated Facial Recognition Systems (AFRS) offer a potential solution for improving facial identification in real-world settings. For example, smart passport "e-Gates" use AFRS to assist with the process of confirming traveler identity (FRONTEX, 2015;MacLeod & McLindin, 2011). In this identity AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 4 verification role, the AFRS creates a numerical vector template to describe the identity of the face in the submitted image at a high level. This vector template is then compared against that created for the second face image, with the angle between the vectors used to return a similarity score. The AFRS returns a "match" decision if the similarity score exceeds a predetermined threshold, and a "mismatch" decision otherwise (see Noyes & Hill, 2021).

Early algorithms achieved performance similar to average novice participants only on high quality imagery (O'Toole et al., 2007). However, many modern algorithms, those that use Deep Convolutional Neural Networks (DCNN), show exceptionally high accuracy across a variety of image factors (Grother et al., 2019), outperforming all but the very best humans (Phillips et al., 2018). Nonetheless, these AFRS still make errors (Hancock et al., 2020;Phillips et al., 2018), and often require human oversight (Fysh & Bindemann, 2018a;MacLeod & McLindin, 2011). At present, an AFRS is likely to serve as a decision aid for humans, rather than a replacement.

Unfortunately, automated decision aids often produce only modest improvements to human judgment accuracy. Because the data on which they base their judgments is imperfect, decision aids, just like human operators, are inherently limited in their accuracy. Ideally, a decision aid and human operator working in combination would achieve performance levels higher than either could achieve alone (Bartlett & McCarley, 2017;Sorkin et al., 2001). In empirical studies, though, decision makers assisted by a moderately-to-highly reliable automated aid frequently fail to achieve even the performance level of the aid by itself (e.g., Bartlett & McCarley, 2017, 2019, 2021Meyer, 2001;Wiegmann et al., 2006). This pattern implies automation disuse, a tendency for operators to disregard or underweight assistance from the aid (Parasuraman & Riley, 1997).

div.head: AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 5
div.p: Consistent with evidence from other domains of aided decision making, data suggest that automation disuse compromises performance in AFRS-aided facial identification tasks.

Though preliminary studies confirm that identification decisions and similarity judgments from human operators are biased toward the recommendations offered by a fictitious AFRS (Barragan et al., 2022;Fysh & Bindemann, 2018a;Howard et al., 2020), further work revealed that aided accuracy is generally suboptimal . Across a series of five pre-registered experiments, participants in a study by completed the Expertise in Facial Comparison Test (EFCT; with and without assistance from an AFRS that provided a binary "same" or "different" judgment for the stimulus faces each trial. In general, while results suggested that response accuracy was higher when participants were assisted by a highly accurate AFRS (> 90.5%) than when they were unassisted, the levels of collaborative performance achieved by the human-AFRS team failed to reach those that the AFRS produced alone. The only exception to this pattern of results came when the aid was of near-chance accuracy (54.8%), a level of performance that the human participants had already surpassed by themselves.

In sum, results indicate that assistance from an AFRS improves human facial identification, but is less helpful than it should be. For purposes of costeffectiveness analyses and operations planning, however, the ability to more accurately predict levels of human-automation team performance would be valuable. In other words, knowing how accurate the human and the AFRS are in isolation, is it possible to anticipate how accurately the automation-aided human will perform? Here, we extend previous work (Bartlett & McCarley, 2017;Boskemper et al., 2022) to benchmark AFRS-aided face matching performance against the predictions of different collaborative decision-making strategies that vary in their efficiency. Our results provide a heuristic for predicting AFRS-aided performance in real-world settings. AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 6

div.head: Signal Detection Theory
div.p: Automation-assisted face matching tasks can be accommodated (Fitousi, 2023;Howard et al., 2020;O'Toole et al., 2000) within the framework of signal detection theory (SDT) (Green & Swets, 1966;Hautus et al., 2022;Stanislaw & Todorov, 1999). A signal detection task requires a decision maker to differentiate between two or more discrete states of the world. The conventional case assumes two states of the world, usually termed signal-plus-noise (i.e., target present) and noise alone events (i.e., target absent) (Green & Swets, 1966;Hautus et al., 2022;Stanislaw & Todorov, 1999). Here, we arbitrarily code a pair of matching faces as a signal-plusnoise event and a pair of non-matching faces as a noise alone event . Under SDT, the decision maker reaches a decision by first encoding evidence for or against the presence of a signal as a unidimensional decision variable, then comparing the decision variable to a response cutoff on the decision axis. Thus, a decision maker performing a one-to-one face matching task might make a "same" or "different" identification decision by assessing whether the level of similarity between the two presented faces reached the cutoff for declaring an identity match. A hit would result when a pair of matching faces exceeds the cutoff level of similarity for a matching judgment, and a false alarm would result when a pair of nonmatching faces exceeds the cutoff. For analysis, hit and false alarm frequencies are generally converted to proportions, the hit rate (HR) and false alarm rate (FAR), respectively.

Signal detection performance is characterized by sensitivity, the decision maker's ability to distinguish signal from noise events, and bias, the decision maker's tendency to favor signal over noise judgments. Assuming the decision variable distributions for signal and noise events are normal with the same variance, sensitivity can be measured with the statistic d' = z(HR)z(FAR), which is the distance between signal and noise distributions measured in units of their common standard deviation. The function z() denotes the inverse normal transformation. If the AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 7 signal and noise distributions are unequal variance, as is common in naturalistic decision-making tasks (Swets, 1986), sensitivity can instead be measured using the statistic, d'e (Egan et al., 1959;Hautus et al., 2022), which is based on the arithmetic average of the standard deviations of the signal-plus-noise and noise alone distributions. Bias can be quantified by the statistic β, the likelihood ratio of a signal event relative to a noise event at the point of the response cutoff. The optimal cutoff placement is a function of signal probability and the relative payoffs attached to correct and incorrect signal and noise judgments (Wickens, 2002). Assuming payoffs are symmetrical for signal and noise trials, the optimal cutoff is the point at which =
where p(signal) is the a priori probability of a signal event.

div.head: Models of Aided Signal Detection
div.p: Automation-aided signal detection can be conceptualized as a form of collaborative decision making or cue combination, in which the human operator integrates their own judgment with the aid's to reach a signal or noise decision. The strategy by which the operator combines these judgments determines the efficiency of aided performance (Bahrami et al., 2010;Sorkin & Dai, 1994;Sorkin et al., 2001). Benchmarking observed performance to the predictions of different information combination strategies therefore provides a natural and intuitive method of characterizing automation dependence (Bartlett & McCarley, 2017). Toward this aim, Bartlett and colleagues (Bartlett & McCarley, 2017;Boskemper et al, 2022) compared observed performance in aided signal detection tasks to the predictions of a set of theory-motivated models that assume different information integration strategies, ranging from perfectly efficient to highly inefficient. Here, we will focus on four models considered by Bartlett and McCarley (2017) The OW model of information integration provides statistically ideal performance in a collaborative decision task (Bahrami et al., 2010;Sorkin & Dai, 1994;Sorkin et al., 2001).

Applied to aided signal detection, the model assumes that the automated aid reports its decision variable (or an invertible transformation of it) to the human operator. In the case of an AFRS in a face matching task, for example, this might be the automated system's estimate of facial similarity are fixed, the OW model allows best-possible performance in an aided signal detection task.

In some cases, a signal detection aid provides the operator only a binary diagnosis, rather than a continuous decision variable. This would be the case, for instance, if an AFRS rendered only match or mismatch judgments in a face matching task, without providing estimates of similarity, as in most of experiments. Under these circumstances, the CC model (Murrell, 1977;Robinson & Sorkin, 1985) allows best-possible performance. The CC model assumes that the operator renders an automation-aided signal-ornoise decision using a standard signal detection process, but adjusts their response cutoff contingent on the aid's binary diagnosis, shifting the cutoff downward following a signal diagnosis from the aid and adjusting it upward following a noise diagnosis. Best-possible performance is obtained when the operator chooses the cutoff placement each trial that is optimal contingent on the aid's diagnosis (Robinson & Sorkin, 1985). Assuming symmetrical payoffs for signal and noise events, optimal cue-contingent cutoff is the point at which =

The PM and CF models produce poorer performance than the OW and optimal CC models, but are potentially simpler for the operator to implement. Both models assume that at the outset of a trial, the aid and the operator reach independent signal or noise decisions. If the aid and operator reach the same decision, the operator issues the agreed-upon response. Otherwise, the operator randomly decides whether to act on their own decision or defer to the aid's. The probability of deferring to the aid differs between the two models. The PM model, motivated by evidence for probability matching behavior in response to system warnings (Bliss et al., 1995;Wiegmann, 2002), assumes that the operator defers to the aid with a probability equal to the aid's mean reliability level. The CF model assumes that the operator defers to the aid with 50%
probability, effectively flipping a coin to determine whether to make an unaided decision or to accept the aid's diagnosis.

The PM and CF models both discard information each trial--either the aid's judgment or the operator's-and both are therefore highly inefficient. Surprisingly, though, multiple experiments have documented automation-aided performance in the range predicted by these two models. In one series of studies (Bartlett & McCarley, 2017, 2019, participants performed a sensory discrimination task either by themselves or with assistance from a 93% reliable decision aid. Aided sensitivity consistently fell in the range predicted by the PM and CF models, lying closer to the PM model when participants were provided trial-by-trial knowledge of their results and closer to the CF model when knowledge of results was withheld. Performance was similar regardless of whether participants received binary or graded diagnoses from the aid. Later AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 10 experiments (Boskemper et al., 2022) using a simulated baggage screening task with a 93%reliable aid found results closely matching the predictions of the CF model. Another study, again using a sensory discrimination task, found that automation-aided performance approached the predictions of the OW model only when the aid's reliability was near chance--that is, when the optimal strategy was to largely disregard the aid's diagnoses (Bartlett & McCarley, 2021). As the aid's reliability increased, aid use efficiency declined, falling to levels of the PM model's predictions when aid reliability was 96%.

div.head: The Current Study
div.p: Experiments to date suggest that when participants perform a signal detection task assisted by a moderately-to-highly reliable aid (93%-reliable or higher), decision making efficiency matches the predictions of the CF and PM models -models that effectively disregard information from one source each trial. The present study asked whether these results would hold in an AFRS-aided one-to-one face matching task, akin to the passport matching task performed by border control personnel.

To answer this question, we report secondary analyses of publicly available data, benchmarking levels of aided performance to the predictions of the OW, CC, PM, and CF models described above. These analyses serve dual purposes; first, to test the generality of earlier model benchmarking exercises (Bartlett & McCarley, 2017, 2019, 2021Boskemper et al., 2022), and second, to identify heuristic models for predicting the performance levels of AFRS-assisted operators in naturalistic tasks.

div.head: Method
div.p: Publicly available data were taken from the five experiments (1a, 1b, 2a, 2b, and 3)

reported by . A detailed report of stimuli and methods is provided there. We summarise the relevant sections of the general method here. To be eligible for participation, individuals had to have been 18 years of age or older, and a resident of the UK, with an accepted completion rate greater than 90% based on their participation in a minimum of 5 previous studies on Prolific. online using Qualtrics survey software. For this task, participants were asked to make a "same" or "different" judgment for 168 pairs of faces in total. These trials were divided into two sets (A and B) of comparable difficulty which were comprised of 42 match and 42 mismatch pairs each, presented in random order. Some participants completed the entire task alone (Control condition), while others were assisted by an automated aid (AFRS) that provided a binary "same" or "different" judgment for each pair of faces in the second half of the task (Aided condition). The order of block (Unaided, Aided) of each set (A, B) was counterbalanced across participants. Unless otherwise noted, participants in the automation-aided group were advised as to the reliability level of the aid.

The five experiments differed as follows. In Experiment 1a, the AFRS operated with an accuracy rate of 97.6% and gave binary identification decisions. In Experiment 1b, the AFRS maintained this level of accuracy but provided an additional estimate of similarity (i.e., confidence) between the two faces. Experiments 2a and 2b both varied the aid's accuracy rate between moderately high and low levels (92.9% vs 54.8%); in Experiment 2a, the participants were directly informed of the aid's accuracy, and in 2b they were told simply that the aid would be correct on "most" trials. Finally, in Experiment 3, the AFRS committed errors on trials that were either difficult or easy for participants, which we will hereon in refer to as positively correlated and inversely correlated conditions, respectively.

div.head: Data Analysis
div.p: We used R (Version 4.3.0; R Core Team, 2023) and the R-packages dplyr (Version 1. Analyses focus on the between-subject manipulation of automated support (Aided vs. Control). For each experiment, we began by reanalyzing performance data using a Bayesian hierarchical signal detection model (Rouder & Lu, 2005). This analysis provided individual-and group-level estimates of ′ for all Aided and Control conditions. We then used the group-level sensitivity estimates for the Control condition to predict Aided sensitivity using each of several benchmark decision strategies, and compared the predicted sensitivity levels for each strategy to the observed levels for the Aided condition.

div.head: Signal Detection Model
div.p: A signal-plus-noise (S+N) event was defined as a trial on which the two stimulus photos were of the same face, and a noise event (N) was defined as a trial on which the photos were of different faces. A hit was therefore defined as a "same" response on an S+N trial, and a false alarm was defined as a "same" response on an N trial. The hierarchical signal detection model assigned binomial likelihood distributions to participants' hit and false alarm counts,
and,
, ∼ Binomial5 , , 426.

Here, ℎ , and , denote the observed counts of hits and false alarms for participant in condition , 0,1 and , denote the corresponding hit and false alarm rates, and 42 is the total number of trials performed by the participant in each of the N and S+N conditions.

Probit-transformed hit and false alarm rates for individual participants were sampled from group-level distributions. The probit (i.e., inverse normal) transformation placed the values on an unbounded scale, allowing the use of normal priors (Rouder & Lu, 2005). Thus,
and

where 2 denote the standard deviations of the participants' hit and false alarm rates within condition . Group level means of the probit-transformed rates were assigned standard normal priors, corresponding to uniform distributions between 0 and 1 on the untransformed rates. The standard deviations within conditions were assigned vague uniform priors between 0 and 10.

The model was fit using a Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling procedure (Kruschke, 2013(Kruschke, , 2015 in JAGS (Plummer, 2019). The estimation procedure was based on four MCMC chains of 1000 burn-in steps and 12,500 estimation steps each. Estimated parameters showed values of the Gelman-Rubin statistic (Gelman & Rubin, 1992) of 1.05 or less, indicating satisfactory convergence of the MCMC chains (Kruschke, 2015).

div.head: AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 15
div.p: Estimates of sensitivity, response accuracy, and benchmark model predictions were calculated from the MCMC outputs. Estimates were calculated at each step of the MCMC chain to provide full posterior distributions of each variable.
The primary measure of sensitivity was ′. Group-level estimates were calculated from probit-transformed estimates of the group-level hit and false alarm rates,

Individual-level estimates, analogously, were calculated using individual-level estimates of probit-transformed hit and false alarm rates. Response accuracy, defined as the proportion of correct responses, was calculated as the average of the hit rate and 1 minus the false alarm rate, and like ′, was estimated at both the group and individual levels.

To check for robustness against violations of the equal variance assumption inherent in ′, we also calculated group-level estimates of the alternative sensitivity measure ′ > (Hautus et al., 2022). Like ′, ′ > is a distance measure of sensitivity that assumes Gaussian distributions of the decision variable. Unlike ′, however, it does not assume that signal and noise distributions share a common standard deviation. Group-level ′ > for condition was calculated with the formula,

where + is the standard deviation of the S+N evidence distribution. Estimates were calculated once under the assumption that + = 0.5, half the standard deviation of the N distribution, and once under the assumption that + = 2.0, twice the standard deviation of the N distribution.
These values were chosen to reflect plausible but fairly extreme violations of the equal-variance assumption (Swets, 1986). In all experiments, the observed differences in sensitivity between

Aided and Control conditions were in the same direction and of similar magnitude whether sensitivity was assessed by ′ or either estimate of ′ > , implying that the observed effects were AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 16 robust over at least the range 0.5 ≤ BCD / B ≤ 2. Estimates of ′ > are reported in the online supplemental materials posted on OSF.io, but are not discussed further here.

div.head: Models of Decision Strategy
div.p: Predictions for the benchmark decision models were generated from the estimated groupmean model parameters as described below. Note that several of the aided decision strategies violate the assumption of equal-variance Gaussian evidence distributions implicit in the calculation of ′. The values reported should therefore be regarded as estimates of equivalent ′, the ′ value to be expected from "a hypothetical simple Gaussian detector which would give the same overall performance as the complex system under study" (Murrell, 1977, p. 7).

div.head: OW Model
div.p: Predicted sensitivity under the OW model, ′ EF , was calculated from the formula (Sorkin & Dai, 1994),
div.formula: ′ OW = L ′ Control O + ′ Aid O .

div.head: CC Model
div.p: To calculate group mean sensitivity under the optimal CC model, ′ CC , we first determined the optimal value of response cutoff contingent on the aid's cue. Optimal relative cutoff placement following a cue of "Match" from the aid was given by,
and optimal placement following a cue of "Mismatch" from the aid was given by,

Here, Aid and Aid , respectively, are the hit and false alarm rate of the automated aid, and ′ Control is the group mean sensitivity in the Control AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 17 condition. Because the aid in all of the current experiments was unbiased, Aid was always equal to 1 − Aid . Aid was equal to the aid's reliability, .

The hit rate for aided trials was a weighted combination of the hit rate for trials on which the aid provided a "Match" cue and the hit rate for trials on which the aid provided a "Mismatch" cue,

Likewise, the false alarm rate for aided trials was a weighted combination of the false alarm rate for trials on which the aid provided a positive cue and the false alarm rate for trials on which the aid provided a negative cue,
HCC and FCC were then transformed to d'CC using the conventional formula (Hautus et al., 2022).

div.head: PM and CF Models
div.p: Hit and false alarm rates under the PM and CF models were a weighted average of the hit and false alarm rates from the unaided operator and the aid. Hit rate and false alarm rates for the PM model, respectively, were,
and,
Hit rate and false alarm rates for the CF model, respectively, were, = 0.5 × Aid + 0.5 × Control , and, CF = 0.5 × Aid + 0.5 × Control .

div.head: Results
div.p: The descriptive statistics we report include the mean and 95% highest-density intervals (HDIs) for the estimated posterior distributions (Kruschke, 2015). The 95% HDI is the region that contains 95% of the posterior distribution mass and within which all values have higher probability than any values outside the region. When presenting difference scores, we also report the proportion of the estimated posterior distribution that lies above or below 0. Values are reported with the nomenclature x% < 0 < y%. For example, 1% < 0 < 99% indicates that 1% of the posterior distribution lies below 0 and 99% lies above.

div.head: Experiment 1a
div.p: In Experiment 1a, participants in the Aided condition were assisted by an automated decision support system with an accuracy rate of 97.6%, corresponding to ′ = 3.962 with an unbiased response cutoff. The aid provided a binary judgment of "same" or "different" each trial.

div.head: AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 19
div.p: Figure presents plots of raw yes rates for Experiment 1a. Values for signal trials are hit rates, values for noise trials are false alarm rates. As expected, hit rates were higher and false alarm rates lower in the Aided condition than in the Control condition.

div.head: Experiment 1b
div.p: Experiment 1b was identical to Experiment 1a except that, in addition to a binary same/different judgment, the aid reported a rating of the similarity between the two faces under comparison each trial. This similarity value was based on the decision variable which the AFRS calculates in order to determine whether a "match" or "mismatch" decision will be rendered, and can be interpreted as a measure of the aid's confidence in its binary judgment. An observer using AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 22 the aid's similarity rating optimally should achieve higher performance in the Aided condition than an observer who is only provided the aid's binary judgment, since the AFRS is less likely to err when the similarity value is either very high or very low (i.e., is far from threshold). Ridgeplots of Bayesian-Estimated ′ (Left) and Accuracy Rates (Right) for Experiment 1b.

div.head: Experiment 2a
div.p: Experiment 2a was identical to Experiment 1a except that it included two automationaided conditions of differing reliability. In one, the aid's judgments were 54.8%-reliable ( ′ = 0.239). In the second, the aid's judgments were 92.9%-reliable ( ′ = 2.930). Figure 5 presents plots of raw yes rates for Experiment 2a. Figures 6 and 7, respectively, present ridgeplots of Bayesian-estimated ′ and accuracy rates for 55%-reliable and 93%-reliable aid conditions of Experiment 2a. Note that the control data in Figures 6 and 7 are identical.

Participants assisted by the 55%-reliable aid performed no better than control participants, .07, 0.02], 83% < 0 < 17% for accuracy. This poor performance level, though, fell roughly in the range predicted by the CC and OW models, the two most efficient decision strategies under consideration. These effects echo the results of Bartlett and McCarley (2021), who reported that the efficiency of automation use improved as the reliability of a decision aid decreases. This pattern reflects a general tendency for operators to disuse decision aids; as the reliability of the aid approaches chance levels, complete disuse becomes the ideal strategy.

div.head: Experiment 2b
div.p: Experiment 2b was identical to Experiment 2a except that participants were not told the aid's reliability before performing the task. Instructions informed the participants in both conditions simply that the aid would be correct on "most" trials. Experiment 3 was similar to Experiment 1a except that it included two automation-aided conditions. In one, the aid made errors on trials that were relatively difficult for human participants (i.e., those that had the lowest unaided human accuracy). In the other, it made errors on trials that were relatively easy for the human participants (i.e., those with the highest human accuracy at baseline). We refer to these as the positively correlated and inversely correlated aid conditions, respectively, referring to the correlations between the aid's and the human participants' judgments. The automated aid was 90.5% reliable ( ′ = 2.618) in both of these conditions. suggests that aided performance was similar across the two aid conditions. In both cases, aided performance fell at or slightly below the levels predicted by the CF model.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Across five pre-registered experiments, asked participants to perform a one-to-one face matching task, making binary identification decisions for pairs of faces. Control participants performed the task unaided, while those in the aided condition worked with assistance from an AFRS. Consistent with findings from earlier studies of automation-aided decision making (e.g., Bartlett & McCarley, 2021;Meyer, 2001;Wickens & Dixon, 2007), reported that participants assisted by moderately-to-highly reliable AFRS performed better than control participants, but failed to reach the sensitivity levels of the automated aid by itself. Their results were consistent with automation disuse (Parasuraman & Riley, 1997), leading the authors to suggest that inefficient human use could contribute to poor AFRS outcomes (see also .

Here, we compared data to the predictions from four models of automation-aided decision making, establishing benchmarks by which system designers and policy makers can assess how well operators are using AFRS, and can predict how much operators' performance might improve with assistance from AFRS. The models differed in their information combination strategies and ranged from perfectly efficient (OW and CC models) to highly inefficient (PM and CF models). Across experiments, we found that participants assisted by moderately-to-highly reliable aids (90.5% or greater accuracy) achieved performance in the range predicted by a CF strategy, the least efficient model under consideration. In other words, aided sensitivity was in the range expected if the operator had simply flipped a coin to resolve their disagreements with the aid. This suboptimal level of performance held whether the aid made only binary diagnoses or provided graded assessments (Experiment 1a vs. 1b), whether participants were explicitly informed of the aid's reliability or were required to infer it (Experiment 2a vs. 2b), and whether the aid's errors were positively or negatively correlated with human errors (Experiment 3). Automation-aided efficiency approached optimal only when the aid's reliability was near chance (54.8%), where the participants' ideal strategy was to effectively ignore the aid's diagnoses (Bartlett & McCarley, 2021).

These results carry two important implications. First, they replicate and extend earlier results documenting performance efficiency in the range of the CF and PM models for participants assisted by moderately-to-highly reliable signal detection aids. Similar results have been found in an abstract sensory discrimination task (Bartlett & McCarley, 2017, 2019, 2021, and a simulated baggage x-ray screening task (Boskemper et al., 2022). This consistency suggests that extreme disuse might be a very general characteristic of automation-assisted decision making.

The second implication, following from the last conclusion, is that the CF strategy provides a useful heuristic model for predicting automation-aided performance in applied signal detection tasks, including one-to-one face matching. More specifically, knowing the operator's unaided response accuracy, system designers can use the CF model to estimate the level of performance that might be achieved with a highly reliable aid. This simple approach can be used to provide a rough upper limit on the level of aided performance that can be expected, which is crucial not only for the purposes of cost-effectiveness planning, but for making informed decisions about the benefits of AFRS implementation with respect to acceptable levels of false positive and false negative identifications (FRONTEX, 2015).

To be clear, although our results match the predictions of the CF model, they do not establish that participants were in fact using that model to make their decisions. Recent model comparison studies have suggested instead that operators rely on a mixture of inefficient strategies for decision aid use, producing results that simply mimic the CF strategy. In particular, cognitive process models of aided signal detection imply a highly suboptimal CC strategy interleaved with a tendency to occasionally act uncritically on the aid's recommendation (Duncan-Reid et al., 2023;Tikhomirov et al., 2023). Additional work will be necessary to generalize and test the robustness of that conclusion. Even though our results are consistent with the use of a CF strategy, a clearer understanding of the strategies by which decision makers use a signal detection aid will be necessary to guide the development of interventions to improve aided performance.

div.head: Constraints on Generality
div.p: As acknowledged in their original paper, present a deliberately simplified model of human-algorithm teaming in the context of an unfamiliar face matching task. Many applied settings use AFRS to identify individuals from large databases (i.e., a one-to-many search), in which case the system returns a candidate list of the faces most similar to the target identity for the human operator to select from (Heyer et al., 2018;. Moreover, participants were members of the general public who were recruited in exchange for a small payment. Future research is needed to test whether our results of suboptimal automation dependence generalize to professionals who perform face matching tasks with the assistance of AFRS in their role (e.g., border control officers). Previous research has shown that operators of automated decision aids come to learn their reliability over time (Ross et al., 2008), which is a requirement of the more efficient models of collaborative decision making tested here. Further research might also test for individual differences in aid use, to examine whether some users consistently engage more efficient collaborative decision making strategies. Preliminary research suggests that individuals who are individually skilled at face matching, and who have high levels of trust in automation (Lee & Moray, 1994), can achieve gains in collaborative accuracy when using AFRS as a decision aid AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 39 . But considered alongside Carragher and Hancock's original findings (2023), our results demonstrate that the average human-algorithm team is highly inefficient in this simplified model of unfamiliar face matching.

figure.figDesc: : the optimal weighting (OW), contingent criterion (CC), probability matching (PM), and coin flip (CF) models. AUTOMATION-AIDED FACE MATCHING 8

Analyses for Experiment 1a were based on a final sample of 99 participants (Aided condition, = 52, = 33.0, = 11.7; Control condition, = 46, = 29.6, = 9.9). Analyses for Experiment 1b were based on a final sample of 95 participants (Aided condition, = 48, = 31.2, = 10.2; Control condition, = 47, = 34.6, = 12.7). Analyses for Experiment 2a were based on a final sample of 136 participants (92.9% reliable condition, = 45, = 31.5, = 9.1; 54.8% reliable condition, = 46, = 34.2, = 9.7; Control condition, = 45, = 29.0, = 9.0). Analyses for Experiment 2b were based on a final sample of 148 participants (92.9% reliable condition, = 52, = 32.5, = 11.5; 54.8% reliable condition, = 49, = 28.0, = 7.7; Control condition, = 47, = 32.8, = 10.6). Analyses for Experiment 3 were based on a final sample of 130 participants (Inversely correlated condition, = 38, = 34.1, = 11.6; Positively correlated condition, = 47, = 32.7, = 10.8; Control condition, = 45, = 33.4, = 10.8).

figure.head: Figure 2
figure.figDesc: presents ridgeplots of Bayesian-estimated ′ (left) and accuracy rates (right) for Experiment 1a. In this and all similar figures to follow, density plots in the bottom two panels of each ridgeplot represent posterior distributions of group mean values in the Control and Aided conditions, and rug plots represent the corresponding median values for individual participants. Density plots in the top four panels of each ridgeplot represent posterior distributions of the values predicted for the Aided condition by the benchmark models. The vertical dashed line in each ridgeplot represents the performance of the automated aid by itself. Consistent with the analyses reported by Carragher and Hancock (2023), ′ and response accuracy were higher in the Aided condition than in the Control condition, Mdiff = 0.79, 95% HDI = [0.43, 1.16], 0% < 0 < 100% for d' and Mdiff = 0.10, 95% HDI = [0.05, 0.14], 0% < 0 < 100% for accuracy. Aided performance was highly inefficient, though, roughly matching the levels predicted by CF strategy of automation use, and falling well below the performance level of the In all violin plots, violins represent empirical data distributions, circles represent means, and error bars represent interquartile ranges. Values for signal trials are hit rates, values for noise trials are false alarm rates.

figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc: Ridgeplots ofBayesian-Estimated ′ (Left) and Accuracy Rates (Right) for Experiment 1a Note. In all ridge plots, the bottom two panels represent estimated values for the empirical Aided and Control conditions and the top four panels represent Aided performance levels predicted by the benchmark models. Density plots represent group mean values. Rug plots represent median values for individual participants. Dashed vertical lines represent performance of the automated aid by itself.

figure.head: Figure 3
figure.figDesc: presents plots of raw yes rates for Experiment 1b.Figure 4presents ridgeplots of Bayesian-estimated ′ (left) and accuracy rates (right) for Experiment 1b. Results closely match those of Experiment 1a. ′ and response accuracy were higher in the Aided condition than in the Control condition, Mdiff = 0.70, 95% HDI = [0.37, 1.02], 0% < 0 < 100% for d' and Mdiff = 0.08, 95% HDI = [0.04, 0.12], 0% < 0 < 100% for accuracy. Aided performance remained highly inefficient, still in the range predicted by CF strategy. Results are consistent with earlier findings(Bartlett & McCarley, 2019) suggesting that operators tend to ignore graded confidence information from an automated signal detection aid.

figure.head: FigureFigure 7
figure.figDesc: Results of the 93%-reliable aid condition matched those of Experiments 1a and 1b. ′ and response accuracy were higher in the Aided conditions than in the Control conditions, Mdiff = 0.74, 95% HDI = [0.43, 1.07], 0% < 0 < 100% for d' and Mdiff = 0.09, 95% HDI = [0.05, 0.13], 0% < 0 < 100% for accuracy, but aided performance was inefficient, roughly in the range predicted by the CF strategy.Ridgeplots of Bayesian-Estimated ′ (Left) and Accuracy Rates (Right) for the 55%-Reliable AidCondition of Experiment 2aRidgeplots ofBayesian-Estimated ′ (Left) and Accuracy Rates (Right) for the 93%-Reliable AidCondition of Experiment 2a

figure.head: Figure 8 FigureFigure 10
figure.figDesc: presents plots of raw yes rates for Experiment 2b.Figures 9 and 10, respectively, present ridgeplots of Bayesian-estimated ′ and accuracy rates for 55%-reliable and 93%-reliable aid conditions of Experiment 2b. The control data in both figures are identical.Ridgeplots of Bayesian-Estimated ′ (Left) and Accuracy Rates (Right) for the 55%-Reliable AidCondition of Experiment 2bRidgeplots of Bayesian-Estimated ′ (Left) and Accuracy Rates (Right) for the 93%-Reliable AidCondition of Experiment 2bResults are similar to those of Experiment 2a. Participants assisted by the 55%-reliable performed no better than control participants, Mdiff = -0.17, 95% HDI = [-0.45, 0.12], 87% < 0 < 13% for d' and Mdiff = -0.02, 95% HDI = [-0.07, 0.02], 88% < 0 < 12% for accuracy, but achieved performance roughly in the range predicted by the CC and OW models. Participants assisted by the 93%-reliable aid outperformed control participants, Mdiff = 0.39, 95% HDI = [0.06, 0.72], 1% < 0 < 99% for d' and Mdiff = 0.05, 95% HDI = [0.01, 0.09], 1% < 0 < 99% for accuracy, but achieved performance only in the range predicted by the CF strategy.

figure.head: Figure 11 Figure 12 Figure
figure.figDesc: presents plots of raw yes rates for Experiment 3. Figures 12 and 13, respectively, present ridgeplots of Bayesian-estimated ′ and accuracy rates for the positively correlated and inversely correlated aid conditions of Experiment 3. The control data in Ridgeplots of Bayesian-Estimated ′ (Left) and Accuracy Rates (Right) for the Positively Correlated Aid Condition of Experiment 3 Ridgeplots of Bayesian-Estimated ′ (Left) and Accuracy Rates (Right) for the Inversely Correlated Aid Condition of Experiment 3 Participants in both aided conditions outperformed the control group, Mdiff = 0.50, 95% HDI = [0.20, 0.80], 0% < 0 < 100% for d' and Mdiff = 0.07, 95% HDI = [0.03, 0.11], 0% < 0 < 100% for accuracy in the positively correlated aid condition, Mdiff = 0.65, 95% HDI = [0.26, 1.04], 0% < 0 < 100% for d' and Mdiff = 0.09, 95% HDI = [0.04, 0.14], 0% < 0 < 100% for accuracy in the inversely correlated aid condition. Visual inspection of Figures 12 and 13

All participants were recruited using Prolific Academic (www.prolific.co)(Palan & Schitter, 2018) and were reimbursed with £2.50 for their participation in an experiment that lasted approximately 30 minutes.
